exclamation.description: Used to give an affirmative response.
Used as a response to someone addressing one or otherwise trying to attract one's attention.
Used to question a remark or ask for more detail about it.
examples: “It should be easy to check.” “Oh yes? How?”
plenty to eat, including hot roast beef sandwiches (yes!)

noun.description: An affirmative answer or decision, especially in voting.
examples: answering with assured and ardent yeses

phrases: “Did it come as a surprise to you?” “Yes and no.”
Yet no one has offered to suggest that Ablett's woes are anything other than those of his own making - but I would argue yes and no?
Asked if he was still doing legal work, he replied: The answer is yes and no in that I have always done wee bits and pieces.
Larissa Behrendt: I think the answer to that is yes and no.
The answer, like so many things in politics, is yes and no.
origin: Old English gēse, gīse, probably from an unrecorded phrase meaning may it be so.
